entry.title: 如何在特朗普2.0 ERA，Microsoft-Tiktok Edition中写（和阅读）头条新闻
entry.content:
路透社的周一报告是在《卫报》上联合的：“微软正在谈论特朗普声称的提克托克”：

唐纳德·特朗普（Donald Trump）建议，微软正在谈判收购Tiktok，他希望看到对该应用程序的竞标战。当被问及微软是否正在谈论购买该应用程序时，美国总统说：“我会说是”，并补充说：“对Tiktok非常感兴趣。 Tiktok非常感兴趣。”

在周一美国总统对空军一号的记者发表评论之后，微软，蒂克托克和bytedance并未立即回应路透社在常规营业时间之外发表评论的要求。

报道的谈判标志着微软第二次在框架中获取Tiktok。在他的第一任期中，特朗普命令蒂克托克（Tiktok）以国家安全问题为由将其美国版本与兽人分开。微软在2020年成为高级投标人，但谈判很快崩溃了，几个月后，特朗普的撤资推动力结束了。

Microsoft正在谈判从Bytedance获取Tiktok的谈话真的吗？还是唐纳德·特朗普（Donald Trump）只是胡扯他的“我会说是”？这份报告仅基于特朗普周一的口头回答，但此后的随访绝对为零。微软昨天报告了其季度收益，并且没有关于Tiktok收购的消息。自2020年以来的几年中，微软已将大量的资本投资到数据中心进行了AI和云计算 - 他们上个季度的220亿美元支出，估计即将到来的一年中的800亿美元支出统治了新闻报道，并分析了他们昨天的业绩。他们还以约700亿美元的价格收购了Activision Blizzard 。我并不是说微软无力获得Tiktok - 我敢肯定，这会引起有关重点的真正问题。但是，昨天结果的报道或他们持有的分析师电话没有什么表明他们正在寻找Tiktok。

无论您是爱特朗普还是恨他（或者，奇怪的是，以某种方式陷入了介于两者之间- 如果您想到的话，请在上课后见我），我们都知道他是个牛头棒。他忙起来。要么（a）微软与派义之间进行了秘密谈判，特朗普对这些会谈有所不道德，他决定对它们进行大声疾呼，但只有在被问到时才会。或（b）当被问到时，他只是说“我会说是”，因为他认为这听起来不错，并加强了他作为世界上最汁的交易者的自我形象。我知道哪个似乎更有可能。

即使不是胡说八道，如果所有新闻报道都必须继续，唐纳德·特朗普（Donald Trump）说“我会说是”，这必须由“也许这是真的”提起。因此，头条新闻最慷慨，应该将其放在首位：“特朗普声称微软正在谈判获得Tiktok”，而不是“ Microsoft正在谈论收购Tiktok，特朗普声称”。

这是踢球者：路透社的原始标题，在reuters.com上，实际上是正确的：“ 特朗普说，微软正在谈判收购tiktok ”。正是《卫报》上的一个人在此上调音了一点点。

★

entry.title: OpenStreetMap社区讨论如何处理美国联邦政府即将指定墨西哥湾为“美国湾”
entry.content:
引人入胜的话题 - 几乎完全是关于出于明显原因的炎症话题的现象。这些是映射和元数​​据书呆子以最秘密的方式来解决困境。我发现它相当舒缓，而且内容丰富，尤其是MinhNguyễn的帖子，他似乎是OpenStreetMap超级用户。第一的：

因此，事实证明，Ungegn实际上并不是个人倾向的决策权。他们的作用是鼓励和促进标准化。他们从字面上发布了有关准则的准则。 在国际法中，最接近海湾名称的权威是国际水文组织。自1953年以来，IHO对海洋和海洋的极限及时冻结，没有任何更新，这显然是因为日本和韩国无法就海上分开的海上同意。也许某个交易商可以把他们带到议价表…

我对特朗普的“美国湾”行政命令的膝盖反应是，地图制造商应该翻一眼，引起混乱的动议并忽略它。但这是不切实际的。地图制造商试图诉诸姓名的权威。还有什么选择？ Google和Apple（和OpenStreetMaps）在地形特征和地理兴趣点的名称上充当了自己的当局？那是不对的。因此，您可能会认为，墨西哥湾是国际水域，因此地图制造商应呼吁国际权威。联合国！但是正如Nguyễn所引用的那样，这并不是联合国关于地理名称的专家群体所做的。

Nguyễn线程中的另一篇文章：

具有讽刺意味的是，西班牙语媒体不得不解释为什么美国海湾在英语中有问题。在西班牙语中， América指的是整个美洲，而不是美国。如果一个人不了解，人们会认为这是对古巴的礼物！当然，这并不能证明将海湾重命名的尝试是合理的，因为意图很清楚，但它确实使他人很容易被他人自己收回。一个更博学的政治家可能选择了佛罗里达海湾，至少具有历史基础，其历史可以追溯到墨西哥湾的同时。但是我们在这里。

从Nguyễn的另一篇文章中，该命令与国会研究服务局（国会图书馆的无党派机构）有关该命令对整个联邦政府的影响的链接。现在，我们已经吸引了更多的书呆子：图书馆员。无论答案是什么，都很复杂。

我不喜欢墨西哥湾的表面上的重命名（更名？）。它是琐碎的，毫无意义的，除了拖钓的恶心，这当然是重点。我不知道苹果会做什么，但是我怀疑，最终，如果内政部确实确实使这张官方的苹果地图会效仿，但也许是像“墨西哥湾（美国海湾）”之类的东西。对于美国的用户。

不过，Google应该简单地做苹果正在做的事情，并且在问题上并且是否实际上是正式的，直到该问题一直保持沉默。我们可以希望的最好的事情是，内部摊位对改变地理名称信息系统（GNIS）的变化，而特朗普则暂时忘记了它。

entry.summary: 整个科技界需要更多的项目，这些项目不试图成为十亿美元（更不用说万亿美元）的想法，而是为了成功地拍摄，因为它是百万美元的想法（或更少的！）。
entry.content:
大卫·皮尔斯（David Pierce）在《边缘》中写道：“鹅卵石智能手表正在卷土重来”：

Migicovsky并没有购买另一个智能手表，而是决定尝试再次卵石。去年，他将自己的最新创业公司（一个名为Beeper ）卖给了Automattic，并于秋季离开了公司。从那时起，他就考虑从头开始启动类似卵石状的产品，认为第二次再次做同样的事情会更容易。 “但是那时我想，如果我只是要求Google打开操作系统怎么办？”他说。感觉就像是一个漫长的镜头，但他知道代码只是在某个地方的Mountain View内部休眠。所以他问。几次。

令Migicovsky感到惊讶的是，Google同意将Pebble OS发布给公众。截至周一， 所有卵石固件都可以在Github上找到，而Migicovsky正在创办一家公司来接他离开的地方。

该公司（由于Google仍然拥有它而无法命名为Cebble），还没有名字。

我对新名称的第一个想法：Rebble-叛逆的卵石回归。我的第二个想法：Quixote-因为这次也不会受到打击。 （Quixote也将是Beeper Mini试图向后访问Android的未经批准的iMessage客户的尝试的好名字。）但是，值得庆幸的是，我听起来不像Migicovsky的目标是沸腾海洋。 （更新：事实证明， Rebble是一个社区项目的名称，以编写新固件以保持旧的卵石表运行。）

Migicovsky，在他的博客上：

您会想象自2012年以来，智能手表就已经发生了很大的发展。我已经尝试了每一个智能手表，但是没有一个为我做。没有人使用我想要的核心功能制作智能手表：

  • 始终在电子纸屏幕上（反光而不是发射。阳光可读。可阅读。可听。不要像明亮的手腕那样分散注意力）
  • 较长的电池寿命（一件事要少的东西。旅行时需要额外的电缆很烦人）
  • 我定期使用的一组核心功能的简单优美的用户体验（讲时间，通知，音乐控制，警报，天气，日历，睡眠/步骤跟踪）
  • 按钮！ （在我的手机上播放/暂停/跳过音乐而不看屏幕）
  • 可黑客（显然您甚至无法为Apple Watch编写自己的表面？那是野性。

如果他们的目标是用于智能手表，那么Playdate是手持游戏，那绝对是可以实现的，如果他们成功，那么从定义上讲，它将很有趣。

整个科技界需要更多的项目，这些项目不试图成为十亿美元的想法（更不用说万亿美元的想法，但很高兴作为百万美元的想法（或更少的！）取得成功。有史以来最好，最受欢迎的电影使好莱坞大片并不大。如果您有史以来最喜欢的电影的清单不包括在预算上制作的一堆，那么您的整个列表可能很糟糕，因为您没有口味。当然，对于音乐，游戏和其他所有内容也是如此。独立艺术经常是伟大的艺术，其创作者的灵魂和痴迷充满了巨大的艺术，而轰动一时的艺术通常是垃圾艺术，只有由无情的企业官僚机构充满。

计算机硬件和软件可以 -应该是- 尝试创建艺术品。

entry.summary: 即使已经在美国用户手机上安装的Tiktok的构建继续运行，该用户无法在新手机或已修复的手机上重新安装Tiktok（或任何Bontedance的其他应用程序），直到这些应用程序又回到应用商店中。
entry.content:
这是我昨天在App Store中通常稳定的“顶级免费下载”列表上的重新介绍的帖子附录。一些改组来自新进入者，例如备受瞩目的AI聊天机器人DeepSeek。但是，其中很多是突然缺乏bondedance的全部应用程序阵容的直接结果：tiktok，capcut，lemon8和Marvel Snap。替代方案正在争夺这些空隙。 [更新，一天后： Marvel Snap又回到了App Store中，因为它现在有一个新发布者。]

蒂克托克（Tiktok）仅一天停电后返回美国的运营服务，使围绕其禁令的愤怒感到震惊。该应用程序停止工作； Tiktok用户没有为禁令做好准备，吓坏了；该应用第二天再次开始工作。 Tiktok粉丝或多或少地回去滚动他们的供稿并闭嘴。争议。

但是争议不应该结束。除非发生变化，否则它将慢慢地煮至最终的沸腾。

没有人真正在谈论这样一个事实，即从法律上讲，在美国，在美国现在在美国被禁止使用，并且已经安装的应用程序的副本只是在继续起作用，因为Tiktok的美国云提供商Oracle和Akamai在Word上还原了服务。特朗普总统在说，尽管明显违反了《帕法卡法》 ，但他们不会为此负责。但是，Apple和Google均未将任何Bontedance的应用程序恢复到App Store或Play Store。这并没有干扰Tiktok通过已经安装在用户手机上的应用程序的副本返回操作，但从长远来看，这是一个无法克服的（尽管增量）。

传统的观点是，Oracle和Akamai有点鲁ck（“如果特朗普说我们很好，我们很好 - 可能出了什么问题，这并不像特朗普曾经改变了主意…… ”），苹果和苹果Google是审慎的，更稳定的（“我们遵循法律的信，将继续遵守法律的信”）。也许这就是这一切。但是，既然我们已经到了这个后期的一周了，那么我开始怀疑这四家公司沿着这些界限而分裂的巧合是否纯粹是巧合。 Tiktok需要在一侧运行的两个云提供商，另一个App Store提供商在另一侧。

随着Tiktok的Cloud Provider访问的关闭，就像断头台。蒂克托克（Tiktok）为美国的每个人都工作，然后繁荣，每个人都关闭了。然后，突然之间，它回来了。

另一方面，被锁定在App Store和Play商店的情况下是一个缓慢的挤压。显然，想到的第一件事不是新用户。没有增长。蒂克托克（Tiktok）已经在美国拥有令人难以置信的用户数量（估计似乎为1.20亿至1.7亿），但没有增长不是增长。

想到的第二件事是没有针对美国用户的应用更新。没有新功能。没有错误修复。没有安全补丁。 Tiktok与大多数受欢迎的应用程序一样，通常会将更新推向App Store，并每两三周播放商店。现在，这已经停止了我们的用户？ Bytedance是否仍将应用程序更新推向世界其他地区的用户？ Tiktok显然有很多美国用户，但其大多数用户都居住在其他地方。

但是第三个因素是最阴险的：即使已经在美国用户手机上安装的tiktok的构建继续运行，该用户无法在新的或已恢复的手机上重新安装Tiktok（或任何Bytedance的其他应用程序），直到这些应用程序回到应用商店。擦拭并还原备份手机？没有更多的tiktok。购买新手机？新手机上没有Tiktok。

特朗普的缓刑是宣称司法部不会在75天内执行法律。如果Bytedance不出售Tiktok - 并且看来他们现在没有更多的意图出售它，而不是在禁令生效之前出售 - 发生了什么？另一个（甚至更违法的）特朗普扩展只能使Tiktok发挥作用，但在应用商店中不可用？因为另一侧也没有发芽：像参议员汤姆·科顿（Tom Cotton）这样的中国鹰 没有移动一英寸。他们可以容忍特朗普的75天缓刑，但没有从他们的整体“出售或被禁止”的立场中开始。

我并不是说这是政府与这些公司之间的幕后情节，但我并不是说这也不是幕后协议。特朗普并没有抱怨苹果和谷歌没有加入。苹果和谷歌似乎都不担心特朗普的愤怒不跟随甲骨文和阿卡玛的潜在客户。立法的目的不是要为美国人伸出tiktok的插头，而是要施加压力（实际上是他们在中国共产党中的老板）来出售该应用程序。立即禁止Tiktok的美国业务引起了Tiktok用户的立即和令人震惊的愤怒 - 事实证明，压力并不是屈服于CCP，而美国政府则在美国政府将人们送回他们心爱的Tiktok。因此，我认为美国方面的每个人都在查看当前的Detente（Tiktok（Tiktok），可以通过应用程序的现有副本可供现有用户使用，但在应用商店中不可用，这是一种仅在bytedance上加剧压力的方式。在几个月的时间里，慢慢地将Tiktok勒死了，而不是一夜之间斩首。

但是，如果CCP站立了，会发生什么？如果他们只是在等待？如果野蛮人是一家普通公司，他们将面临经济压力，以屈服和出售。但是，CCP并没有承受任何经济压力，以允许出售。说出您对中国政府的意愿，但他们并不缺乏耐心。那会发生什么，当单词开始在Tiktok粉丝之间传播以不升级手机时，以免他们无法访问该应用程序？苹果会对这有一些强烈的感觉。

;
entry.title: ★我关于Tiktok目前在美国的半获取的spitball理论
Google Maps将仅适用于墨西哥湾的“美国湾”，仅适用于美国用户
entry.content:
Google，在X上的公告中：

我们收到了有关在Google Maps中命名的一些问题。当政府官方资料中更新名称时，我们有一个长期的练习来应用名称更改。

对于美国的地理特征，这是更新地理名称信息系统（GNIS）的时间。发生这种情况时，我们将迅速更新美国的Google Maps，以显示麦金莱山和美国海湾。

同样长期的练习：当国家 /地区之间的正式名称变化时，用户看到了其正式的本地名称。世界其他人都看到两个名字。这也适用于这里。

詹妮弗·埃里亚斯（Jennifer Elias），报道CNBC ：

CNBC获悉，Google的地图部门将美国重新分类为“敏感国家”，它保留了严格的政府和边境纠纷的州的名称。 [...]

根据内部通信，地图部门内的一些团队成员被命令紧急更改位置名称，并将美国从“非敏感”重新分类为“敏感”。更改给出了罕见的“ P0”订单，这意味着它具有最高的优先级，并立即通知员工，并指示丢弃他们在处理它的工作。

Google的命令指出，应将美国湾变更类似于波斯湾的对待，在阿拉伯国家，该海湾在Google Maps上显示为阿拉伯湾。

Apple没有关于Apple Map将如何处理此方法的消息。 （我已经要求发表评论；如果得到答案，将更新。）将Denali重新命名为麦金莱山似乎很容易遵守地图。一个国家命名自己的山脉。如果奥巴马可以重命名，特朗普可以重新命名。

但是，墨西哥湾是国际水域，直到几周前特朗普开始谈论它之前，它的名字才辩论。 Google（也许还有苹果）有一项政策，他们只是遵循GNIS的命名惯例似乎不仅是明智的，而且是完全无争议的……直到现在。

世界上有三个国家不使用公制系统作为其官方措施单位：美国，利比里亚和缅甸。我希望将其称为“美国海湾”的人会更少 - 即，一个人。

★

entry.summary: OpenVibe将Mulitple网络的多个帐户融合到一个时间表中，这很有趣，但对我来说却不是 - 我不确定它 *是 *。
entry.content:
萨拉·佩雷斯（ Sarah Perez）

OpenVibe 于2024年启动，最初支持三个更突出的开放社交网络，所有这些网络都使用不同的协议运行：Mastodon使用ActivityPub，Bluesky在协议上运行，NOSTR Powers Power power power surn powers powers power super power support power super power s of第三方应用程序。随后，OpenVibe 增加了对Instagram线程的支持，因为该应用程序与ActivityPub进一步集成在一起，并向开发人员社区开放。

正如首席执行官Matej Svancer当时所解释的那样，他的应用程序背后的想法是为用户提供更友好，更易于使用的网关，以向开放的社交网络提供。由于这些网络使用的不同协议，对于最终不得不切换应用程序或将其参与度限制为首选平台的新移民来说可能很难。

但是，OpenVibe不仅让人们在合并的时间表中与所有这些服务的朋友保持联系，还允许一次交叉启动到多个网络。

我只是尝试了一下，我的看法是， OpenVibe绝对有趣，但这并不适合我，我不确定它是谁。我签署了据称支持的所有三个个人帐户： Bluesky ， Mastodon和Threads 。我得到了一个主页，将我蓝调和Mastodon帐户的所有帖子捣碎在一起。我没有看到与线程有关的任何错误，但是我看不到线程中的任何帖子。这是有道理的，因为线程不提供允许完整的第三方客户的API。线程确实有一个用于发布的API，因此我认为我的线程帐户是只写的。不过，OpenVibe的网站和应用程序本身使我似乎应该从主题时间表中看到内容。 （也许我不是因为我几周前关闭了与线程帐户的“联邦政府共享” -因为我更喜欢将这些网络分开。但是，如果这是问题的话，OpenVibe并不能解释我需要重新启用它）

我真的看不到将两个（或更多！）不同社交网络的推文融合到一个统一的时间表中。对我来说，这只是令人困惑。我不喜欢当前的情况，三个完全分开的，蓬勃发展的社交网络每个都值得我注意（更不用说第四个，x，仍然有点了）。但是，当我使用每个平台时，我想使用专用于每个平台的客户端。这些平台在不同程度上都具有不同的特征，并且它们肯定具有不同的共鸣和文化规范。假装它们都形成一个大的（小写）元平台并不能使这种假装具有凝聚力。将它们全部融合在一起并不简单。听起来更简单，但实际上是更刺眼的。

这可能以任何方式吸引“新移民”的想法对我来说是香蕉。从定义上讲，从多个网络将多个帐户流式传输到一个时间表的概念有点高。根据我的经验，出于非常明显的原因，休闲社交网络用户仅使用第一方客户。即使使用一个名为Ivory的应用程序来访问一个名为Mastodon的社交网络的想法，他们也使他们感到困惑。向他们解释为什么他们可能想使用名为OpenVibe的应用程序访问Mastodon，Bluesky和Threads（以及怪异的区块链NOSTR）的想法就像试图向您的狗解释为什么他们应该远离垃圾。有一个针对第三方客户的市场（或者至少我希望有），但是该市场不是由“新移民”组成的。

另外，OpenVibe不是一个好应用。它看起来不太好，自定义字体有些卡通（我觉得这既没有吸引力又令人反感），有很多灰白色的低对比度象征和文本，而且最糟糕的是似乎定期更新您的供稿，何时进行更新，它会在您查看时刷新和滚动时间表。这就像在您在页面中间阅读时自动翻页。几分钟后，当您离开并回到应用程序时，时间轴需要重新加载，这有助于该应用程序感觉很慢。整体外观，感觉和布局都显示“通用的Twitter风格的社交网络”。

我确实使用了，并且非常看到羊角面包的点，这是一个多网络应用程序，用于交叉播放到Mastodon，Threads和Bluesky。羊角面包不是从这些平台中消费内容的客户；它只是向这些平台发送新帖子的工具。

如果Tapbots的上述象牙添加了对Bluesky帐户的支持，我会很喜欢它。但是，当我使用象牙色（如我在使用Tweetbot多年之前，它在它之前）时，我看不到 - 也不想看到 - 来自所有配置的帐户的单个时间表。我想在多个帐户之间切换，每个帐户都有自己的离散时间表。 OpenVibe在许多方面都与象牙相反，从其口号开始：“所有分散的社交网络，单个时间表”。

Addendum，2025年1月30日：我对OpenVibe从来没有足够的距离来授予它发送通知的许可，但是Kim Slawson确实做到了，并且OpenVibe的通知无用。他们没有告诉您有关您通知的帖子的任何有用的东西 - 您知道，例如他们说的话或谁发布了它们，而是说“新通知正在等待您！”所以毫无用处，真是太神奇了。

詹妮·里德（Jenni Reid）和亚历克斯·哈林（Alex Harring），报道CNBC：

NVIDIA和其他美国技术公司周一下跌，这是全球抛售的一部分，因为中国初创公司DeepSeek引起了人们对人工智能和美国在该行业领导的竞争力的担忧。

NVIDIA是AI Hype的主要受益者的CHIP设计师，最后一次下跌了17.3％。因此，Megacap Tech股票有望使其自2020年3月以来最糟糕的一天。

简而言之，很广泛地认为，领先的模型培训和推理需要最高的高端硬件 - 该硬件（尤其是用于培训）几乎完全来自NVIDIA。假设的假设是，任何试图在这个激烈竞争的领域竞争的公司 - 对行业，文化和国家安全具有巨大影响的领域，都必须排队购买（或出租）大量的计算能力，专门提供最佳的计算能力来自NVIDIA的系统。由于拜登政府的出口禁令，该硬件（至少在法律上至少是合法）不可用的。 DeepSeek工程师发现并实施了多种巨大的效率提高，使公司可以使用远不足的硬件以较低的价格培训其最新车型，并在迄今为止前所未有的内存限制下进行推断。 DeepSeek的成就使有关AI状态的几种常规观念过时了。我的链接在本段中的几个句子上是14天前的WSJ报告，现在感觉到它的历史至少可以追溯到14个月前。

最令人震惊的结果是，当今NVIDIA的股价受到17％的命中率，其市值约为3500亿美元。 Google下跌了约4％，Microsoft下跌了2％，但Meta增长了1％，Apple增长了3％以上。我认为市场反应非常明显：

  • Nvidia进行了前所未有的殴打。 3500亿美元超过Verizon和AT＆T的联合市值（每个价值约1700亿美元）。但是，恩维迪亚（Nvidia）一直处于前所未有的地位，即使是从迪索克（Deepseek）出发的这些突破，仍然存在。 NVIDIA的高飞估值反映了其作为AI基本硬件公司的前所未有的立场。 NVIDIA的位置（后R1）仍然是必不可少的 - 只是每个人都认为的那么重要。因此，发型。但是，Nvidia仍然是世界上第三大的公司 - 今天遭到了巨大的投资，但绝不崩溃。

  • TSMC和Broadcom今天也受到了巨大的打击（分别为-13％和-17％）。今天，成为一家“芯片公司”看上去并不像上周那样甜美。

  • 如果Openai被公开交易，我怀疑它可能已经崩溃了 - 今天将面临的抛售可能触发了停止交易的紧急措施。

  • 微软一直远离Openai ，但仍然像其他公司一样与他们交织在一起。 （回想一下，苹果在四个月前就离开了Openai的大笔投资。）-2％的命中率是正确的。

  • DeepSeek的成就最广泛的含义是，真正的AI将比预期的要便宜，更公开，比预期的要早。这对Google来说是个坏消息，Google的整个企业价值基于他们在这些领域的无懈可击和可持续的领先优势。 Google不必担心竞争对手会竞争他们的搜索。他们必须担心“搜索”的整个领域都在商品化的风口浪尖上。因此-4％命中。

  • 元认为，随着生成性AI的价格便宜，元的想法是好处。这就是为什么Meta自己的AI努力是Kinda开源的原因。 Meta与DeepSeek无关，但是DeepSeek的成就似乎与Meta对AI的利益完全一致。

  • 苹果的福利是间接的，至少从DeepSeek的突破中至少有两种方式。首先，RAM约束硬件的推理功能的大幅度提高表明，Apple的消费设备很快将能够在本地执行更多的AI计算。 Apple Silicon的共享内存体系结构非常适合这一点，并且仍然没有行业中其他任何人的重复。其次，苹果几十年来与NVIDIA的僵化关系突然看起来不那么问题。

entry.summary: 我看到有关USB-C端口太薄的手机的四个可能的未来。
entry.content:
多米尼克·普雷斯顿（Dominic Preston）为《边缘》写道：“ Oppo的下一个可折叠与USB-C所允许的稀薄” ：

在过去的一周中，Oppo一直在稳步嘲笑中国社交网络微博上的发现N5。查找系列产品经理周Yibao现在共享了突出显示大小的照片，并补充说，使其更薄的障碍现在是“充电端口的极限”。 [...]

该公司声称发现N5是迄今为止最薄的可折叠。该标题目前由荣誉魔术V3持有，该标题在打开时厚4.35毫米，这意味着发现N5必须接近4mm。这就解释了为什么它看起来大约是8.25mm iPhone 16 Pro Max的一半，并在照片中显示。作为参考，USB-C端口至少为2.6mm。

我看到四个可能的未来：

（a）我们永远不会看到比4毫米更薄的手机，USB-C将永远与我们同在。

（b）当我们开始获得比USB-C允许的手机较薄时，它们完全放弃了插入式端口，并专门移动到诱导连接（例如MAGSAFE），以用于充电和数据。

（c）一家或多家公司（很可能是苹果）设计了一个专有的充电和数据端口，该端口比USB-C更薄。

（d）USB联盟为USB-C连接器设计了一个行业标准，较薄的后继产品，欧盟迅速更新其法规，以允许其作为USB-C的替代方案。

选项（a）使我保证错误。我们迟早会看到对USB-C端口太薄的手机。唯一的问题是何时。

选项（b）对于以消费者为目标的设备来说似乎是完全合理的，但是目前，在具有USB-C端口的iPhone Pro模型中启用了从字面上的专业口径视频功能，目前不可能通过任何现有的电感连接器来提供。由于USB无处不在，甚至没有人尝试建立用于高速数据传输的电感连接器。数据传输可能是在不久的将来保留USB-C上专业电话的限制因素，但是最近iPad型号的智能连接器处理充电和数据（尽管低速数据传输，但仅用于触控板和键盘输入）。有史以来最薄的iPhone 17“空气”模型预计将与iPhone 17 Pro型号一起使用，而不是代替它们。如果事实证明它很受欢迎，我可以看到不久的将来iPhone“空气”掉落其USB-C端口，并且仅用于收费的MAGSAFE，所有数据传输都会无线进行（这意味着通过蓝牙和Wi-Fi进行了空气） ，虽然iPhone Pro型号，具有较厚的电池和更多更好的相机，但请保留其USB-C端口几年，直到它们也获得感应性充电独家，也许具有突破性的磁性智能连接器，以支持高速数据传输。我怀疑这是我们看到的道路，即提供太微薄的USB-C-C-port手机和平板电脑。而且我相信它将整齐地保留在欧盟的充电港口法规中，但会刺激这些法规的支持者，因为苹果不太可能选择使这样的超智能连接器成为开放标准。 （欧盟USB-C授权仅适用于充电端口的原因，这就是为什么Apple Watch的原因，列举了一个仅通过专有连接器向归纳收费的设备的突出示例，该设备仍在那里可用。）

当然，选项（c）将在欧盟中不允许，这意味着这些手机要么不会在欧盟出售，要么是使其制造的公司（面对现实，将是苹果）在欧盟出售的模型，该模型省略了专有港口，仅通过MagSafe/Qi收费。我的Spidey-Sense说，这是不值得的，因此不会发生。我可以想象一个端口和连接器比USB-C更薄 - 看起来像闪电，但较薄 - 但是要保持任何形式的结构刚度，它就不会比USB-C更薄，因此不会' t可以创建比USB-C端口允许的薄的手机或平板电脑。我可以想象的是手机和平板电脑，更像是厚度的信用卡。但是，需要解决许多工程挑战才能到达那里 - 电池技术，展示技术，芯片效率，可能还有十几个。

选项（d）让我笑了，只是想着它。

苹果公司（Apple Inc.

据知情人士说，负责计划管理的副总裁沃拉斯（Vorrath）本周被转移到苹果的人工智能和机器学习部门。她说，她将成为AI负责人约翰·吉安南德里亚（John Giannandrea）的顶级代理人，他们要求不认同，因为这一变化尚未公开宣布。 [...]

多年来，沃拉斯（Vorrath）在苹果的几项最大努力中占据了一席之地。在2000年代中期，她被选为原始iPhone软件组的项目管理，并为消费者准备了标志性设备。直到2019年，她在使用Vision Pro软件之前监督了iPhone，iPad和Mac操作系统的项目管理。

沃拉斯（Vorrath）的名字以某种方式从未出现在大胆的火球上，但是她在苹果（Apple）中闻名，甚至是传奇人物，甚至是因为她在管理原始iPhone的软件创建和开发中的领导角色，实际上是Scott Forstall担任Scott Forstall的参谋长。她的声誉是她是一位出色的经理 - 她做得糟透了，知道如何运输，才华横溢的人喜欢并为她工作而壮成长。但是在苹果以外，她在很大程度上飞到了雷达下，这仅强调了她是苹果人的苹果人多少。

entry.summary: 带有苹果情报的Siri对体育琐事问题的自信但令人尴尬的错误答案，包括著名的（超级碗）和晦涩难懂（北达科他州高中篮球）。
entry.content:
当我昨天撰写有关苹果情报的当前状态时，我提到当被问及一个简单的问题“谁赢得超级碗13？”时，Siri是多么愚蠢和可笑的错误，并提到这个特定的例子来自一个朋友。那个朋友是保罗·卡法西斯（Paul Kafasis），他拿走了它并彻底追捕它，问西里（Siri）“谁赢得了超级碗__？”对于1到60的每个数字。

他在一只脚海啸中记录结果的报告完全令人发指：

那么，Siri是怎么做的？凭借绝对最慈善的解释，Siri正确地为58个超级碗中的20个获得了冠军。这绝对是一个糟糕的34％的完成百分比。如果Siri是四分卫，那将是从NFL中击出的。

Siri曾经曾经设法连续四年正确（超级碗IX到XII），但前提是我们为错误的原因提供了正确的答案。更真实地，它连续三次正确回答了三个（超级碗VII，通过VII，XXXV通过XXVII，通过Lix进行LVII）。在最糟糕的情况下，它连续出现了惊人的15个错误（超级碗XVII到XXXII）。最有趣的是，它以他们尚未获得的惊人的33次超级碗胜利归功于费城老鹰队，与他们拥有的1胜。

下面，我按顺序收集了我最喜欢的十二个回答。

卡法西斯（Kafasis）所选的答复绝对很有趣，他在电子表格中记录了每一个结果，可同时以Excel和PDF格式下载。只需阅读。

这真是令人难以置信的是，Siri对如此受欢迎的主题有多愚蠢。如果您猜测Siri可以将超级碗的一半得到一半，那您就输了，甚至还没有那么近。

其他答案引擎可以用plomber处理相同的问题。我没有从超级碗1到60进行全面测试，因为我很懒惰，但是在该范围内的一些随机数进行了检查，这表明其他所有Quest-a-question-get-get-get-n-An-Answer代理I个人使用使它们都正确。我尝试了Chatgpt，Kagi，Duckduckgo和Google。这四个人甚至在可以说是关于超级碗59和60的获胜者的问题上都表现出色的，这些问题尚未播放。例如，询问超级碗59的获胜者，Kagi的“快速答案” 1开始：“超级碗59计划于2025年2月9日举行。截至目前，比赛尚未发生，因此没有赢家，因此没有赢家报告。”

超级碗冠军并不是一个晦涩的话题，例如问：“谁赢得了2004年北达科他高中男孩的州篮球冠军？” - 我只是完全退出了我的屁股，但令人惊讶的是，卡吉（Kagi）正确回答了A类，Chatgpt对A级和B类正确回答，并提供了与此视频的链接，该视频涉及A级A冠军游戏YouTube 。太神奇了！我选择了一个晦涩的状态（对北方或南部的达科丹人没有冒犯），这是过去一年，而且我个人最关心的高中运动。 Kagi和Chatgpt都做对了。 （我会给kagi a a，并为命名两个班级的冠军，并为YouTube链接的a+上方的额外信用。）

DuckDuckgo获得了部分荣誉：其最佳搜索结果是该网页的链接，该网页列出了所有以前的男孩篮球州冠军，可以追溯到1914年。这是搜索引擎的完美答案。但是，作为答案引擎，达克杜克戈（Duckduckgo）的“ AI辅助”功能回答说：“狄金森·三位一体（Dickinson Trinity）赢得了2004年北达科他州高中男孩州篮球锦标赛的冠军。”从技术上讲，这是正确的，但是Dickinson Trinity是2004年B级冠军，这是小型学校的班级。我提出的问题对此很模棱两可，因为就像我说的那样，我把它从屁股上拉出来，不知道北达科他州有两个学校大小的高中运动课程。但是，如果一个答案引擎只会命名一个冠军，那么应该为A级。

But it's even worse than that, because old Siri, without Apple Intelligence, at least recognizes that Siri itself doesn't know the answer and provides a genuinely helpful response by providing a list of links to the web, all of which contain accurate information pertaining to the question. Siri with Apple Intelligence, with ChatGPT integration enabled, is a massive regression.

If there's any consolation for the Siri team at Apple, it's that one other company's AI-powered answer engine gave me an embarrassingly wrong response when asked for the 2004 North Dakota boys' basketball champions: Google. Google's regular web search results for that query are OK, with the top link being the same PDF file , with results that only run through 2019, that old pre-AI Siri offered as its first result. If anything, believe it or not, Google's AI Overview gave me the single worst answer in this whole saga, the first time I tried:

The Lower Brule boys' basketball team has never won a state championship, but has finished as the Class B runner-up in the state tournament twice in recent years — in 2022 and 2023. which is the same technically correct, but not ideal answer that DuckDuckGo gave. (Technically correct insofar as Dickinson Trinity won the 2004 Class B boys' championship.) Asked a third and fourth time, Google AI Overview stuck with Dickinson, so perhaps I got (un)lucky with its first boneheaded response.

Misery loves company they say, so perhaps Apple should, as they've hinted since WWDC last June , partner with Google to add Gemini as another “world knowledge” partner to power — or is it weaken? — Apple Intelligence.

entry.title: [Sponsor] Fucking Amazon
Southern California Wildfire Relief: Consider Donating to the Red Cross Through Apple
entry.content:
苹果：

Click the amount you wish to contribute, then click Donate and Apple will transfer 100% of your contribution to the American Red Cross in support of people impacted by the 2025 Southern California wildfires.

Apple has prominent links to its Red Cross donation form on the web and in the App Store. They've been doing this after catastrophes and disasters around the world for a long time . On the surface, it's great because it's so easy. Apple already has your saved credentials so it takes just a few taps or clicks to donate. You can measure the time to donate in seconds, not minutes.

But an under-appreciated aspect of Apple acting as a front-end to the Red Cross is that your donation remains completely private. There's quite a lot of small print on the donation screen, which starts:

Because Apple is not sharing your personal information with the American Red Cross, the American Red Cross is unable to further acknowledge your donation. You will receive an email receipt from Apple, which will serve as the only record of your donation. The donation will also appear on your credit card statement as a transaction with Apple. You do not purchase any goods or receive any services from Apple by making a donation. Any donation collected by Apple is collected in the name, and on behalf, of the American Red Cross. This donation may not qualify for any tax deduction or other tax benefits. By donating through Apple, you acknowledge that any tax consequences to you in making the donation (including, but not limited to, ensuring you have sufficient documentation to claim any applicable tax deduction) shall be your responsibility. Apple Account credit cannot be used to make a donation. Apple will transfer 100% of your contribution to the American Red Cross in support of people impacted by the 2025 Southern California wildfires (including Los Angeles, San Luis Obispo, Kern, Santa Barbara, Ventura, San Bernardino, Orange, Riverside, San Diego and Imperial Counties).

This sounds like a bunch of ignorable legalese but what it really means is quite interesting. You're not giving to the Red Cross through this. You're giving money to Apple, and Apple will then transfer 100 percent of it to the Red Cross. I'm almost certain, for example, that Apple is covering the cost of the card transaction fees.

By donating this way, you will never get junk mail, email, or text messages from the Red Cross, or from any “partner” of the Red Cross, soliciting additional donations, because the Red Cross will never get your name, address, or数字。 All they get is your money.

Back in August I wrote about how my political solicitations via SMS had gotten so out of control, so downright annoying, that my wife and I had scaled back our donations to political campaigns, because it was obvious that previous campaigns we had donated to had shared or sold our information. We'd been put on a Suckers List.

The same thing, sadly, happens with charities. People generally don't want to admit to selfishness, but I will. When I give money to a charitable cause, I always look for the checkboxes to opt out of being contacted by them in the future. When it happens anyway, I get annoyed, and I become reluctant to give to that charity again. And because it has happened repeatedly, it's made me at least somewhat more reluctant to give to any charitable cause in the first place. I know I'm not alone in feeling that way.

When you donate to the Red Cross via Apple, that concern is off the table. Apple won't emphasize that aspect of this, because they don't want to throw the Red Cross under the proverbial bus, but I will. An underrated aspect of privacy is the desire simply not to be annoyed.

entry.title: The Ship That Leaks From the Top Is Back
entry.content:
From a multi-byline profile of Stephen Miller in The New York Times last week:

Mr. Miller told Mr. Zuckerberg that he had an opportunity to help reform America, but it would be on President-elect Donald J. Trump's terms. He made clear that Mr. Trump would crack down on immigration and go to war against the diversity, equity and inclusion, or DEI, culture that had been embraced by Meta and much of corporate America in recent years.

Mr. Zuckerberg was amenable. He signaled to Mr. Miller and his colleagues, including other senior Trump advisers, that he would do nothing to obstruct the Trump agenda, according to three people with knowledge of the meeting, who asked for anonymity to discuss a private conversation. Mr. Zuckerberg said he would instead focus solely on building tech products.

Mr. Zuckerberg blamed his former chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, for an inclusivity initiative at Facebook that encouraged employees' self-expression in the workplace, according to one of the people with knowledge of the meeting. He said new guidelines and a series of layoffs amounted to a reset and that more changes were coming.

This account of the meeting clearly leaked from Trump's side, not Meta's side. The tone of it is that Miller told Zuckerberg to jump, and that Zuck obsequiously and gladly responded “How high?”

Zuckerberg scrambled for cover, posting a “Sheryl did amazing work at Meta and will forever be a legend in the industry [...]” tweet to Threads , followed by a coordinated “Thank you, @zuck. I will always be grateful for the many years we spent building a great business together [...]” reply from Sandberg . (Sandberg, who left Meta in 2022, only posted once to Threads in all of 2024. There's a good chance this will be her only post in 2025.)

Zuckerberg, politically, seems in way over his head. The first Trump administration was infamous for its leaks . They barely hid it. The whole Trump brand is about brazenness. For decades, Trump was known to call reporters in New York under the guise of “John Miller” or “John Barron” , who were ostensibly public relations spokesmen representing Trump. But it was just him — and he didn't even disguise his voice. He just did it.

So of course Stephen Miller (or Miller's equivalent of John Barron) leaked the confidential nature of his discussion with Zuckerberg to The New York Times, because it made Miller look dominating and Zuckerberg look dominated. Even though it's painfully obvious to anyone who sees this story that anything confidential they tell Stephen Miller might get leaked if it makes Miller look good. It's like a perversion of your Miranda rights, a Miranda wrongs if you will: Anything you say to anyone in the Trump administration can and will be used against you in leaks to the media.

You don't see stories like this about Cook or Nadella or Bezos, because I think those guys have the good sense to keep their mouths shut and just nod their heads. (Not Musk, though. When Trump and Musk eventually divorce in a spectacular flame-out, we'll be deluged with stories about what Musk said in supposed confidence.)

entry.title: Next Week's iOS 18.3 and MacOS 15.3 Updates Will Enable Apple Intelligence During Onboarding
entry.content:
From Apple's developer release notes for iOS 18.3, now at release candidate (RC) status:

For users new or upgrading to iOS 18.3, Apple Intelligence will be enabled automatically during iPhone onboarding. Users will have access to Apple Intelligence features after setting up their devices. To disable Apple Intelligence, users will need to navigate to the Apple Intelligence & Siri Settings pane and turn off the Apple Intelligence toggle. This will disable Apple Intelligence features on their device.

Same for MacOS 15.3 Sequoia, which is also at RC status and expected next week.

I have mixed feelings about this decision. It's pretty obvious that Apple Intelligence has a slew of shortcomings. It's the nature of the beast, though, that it's always going to have some shortcomings. Human intelligence, which to date remains the gold standard for intelligence in general, has some pretty glaring shortcomings, so it's unsurprising that all artificial intelligence systems still do too. (Perhaps that's a good metric for defining the next inflection point, now that the Turing Test has been passed: When humans need to ask AI systems to explain their own shortcomings, because we're no longer smart enough to detect them ourselves.)

So the bar shouldn't be “has obvious shortcomings”. It's whether Apple Intelligence is good enough. Compared to other systems, like ChatGPT, no, it's not good enough. But Apple has been enabling Siri by default since 2011. And Siri, today, is arguably worse than it's ever been when compared to the state of the art. A friend just sent me this screenshot after asking Siri “Who won Super Bowl 13?” and getting this answer: “Philadelphia Eagles Super Bowl Lii • Winner”. In addition to wrongly casing the Roman numerals, LII is 52, not 13. The only way Siri could have been more wrong would be if the Eagles hadn't even won Super Bowl 52. I just tried the same question — “Who won Super Bowl 13?” — on both my iPhone running iOS 18.3 RC1 and my Mac running MacOS 15.1.1, and Siri gave me the same wrong answer, on both devices, both when the question was spoken aloud and when it was typed: “Philadelphia Eagles Super Bowl Lii • Winner”. Siri, today, is an unfunny joke.

But so I think it's reasonable to ask whether Apple Intelligence is as good as Siri. I'd say yes, that's about how good Apple Intelligence is. In fact, I'd say several of the Apple Intelligence features — Clean Up in Photos, and notification summaries — are better than Siri. So if Siri has been on by default for over a decade, sure, Apple should go ahead and turn Apple Intelligence on by default too.

I think there could be significant benefit to turning it on by default, sort of in the spirit of dogfooding . Enabling Apple Intelligence features by default will increase the pressure on Apple to keep improving it at a fast clip. It's also the case that none of Apple Intelligence's features, with the possible exception of notification summaries, are in the user's face at all. You have to invoke them to use them. If you don't want them — or don't even know about them — you won't notice anything different once they're enabled by default. Apple may or may not be over-indexing on Apple Intelligence, but, thankfully, they're not shoving it in users' faces.

But, as I wrote two weeks ago , enabling it by default for all users really puts the lie to their claim that all of Apple Intelligence is “beta”. If it's not just merely shipping to all users, but now enabled by default, that's not beta. That's just buggy .

★

entry.title: Remember Clips?
entry.content:
Wesley Hilliard, writing for AppleInsider regarding Edits , Meta's pre-announced mobile-first video editing app:

Despite that, many apps and features on iPhone toe the line between fun tool and social platform. One of those tools was Clips, which arrived in 2017 to little fanfare and has been forgotten since.

Meta and ByteDance have a reason to push their respective video editing apps — brand synergy. More users mean more data, more content, and more ad revenue. Apple, however, doesn't have the same motivation.

While Apple would likely love to see users flock to Clips, it would mean entering a race to satisfy a wave of several million customers in an app and interface that was never really more than a proof of concept. It would be a money pit with very little reward as Apple doesn't have a social platform to drive users to or a way to monetize the app.

I completely agree with Hilliard that the announcement of Edits is the perfect time to mention Clips. I completely disagree with him that Apple has no motivation to dedicate itself to the task of making Clips incredible.

A mobile-first video editor isn't a “money pit”. It's an app. Apple makes a lot of apps, and they could easily afford to assign a team to make Clips truly great. It's no different than 20–25 years ago, when Apple dedicated itself to making iMovie and Final Cut both great apps. It's no different than the motivation to create GarageBand. The monetization wouldn't be direct; it would be downstream of the general idea that if you're editing videos for social media on your phone, the best app to do it with is from Apple and it's exclusively available on iPhone. The idea is that Apple doesn't just make the best computing devices for artists, writers, and creators, but they also make some of the best apps for those fields too.

There are actually a lot of interesting UI ideas in Clips. But if Apple isn't interested in making Clips truly great for people who actually love editing videos using their phones, they should just abandon it. Make it great or give up. Keeping it around as an also-ran that no one uses is a bad look. This is the sort of thing Apple should pride itself on: best-of-breed creative tools.

I don't know if Edits is a rip-off of CapCut or not, but it's definitely not a rip-off of Clips. It's a good rule of thumb that when Apple succeeds at something, it gets ripped off. The better the Apple product, the more shamelessly it gets copied . Apple should make Clips into an iOS video editing app that everyone rips off shamelessly.

Apple has been planning to introduce the home hub in March, but it may take longer to reach consumers. The device's new operating system — code-named Pebble — is heavily tied to App Intents features coming in iOS 18.4 and iOS 19, so it's plausible that the hardware itself will ship a bit later.

How many Apple products that miss “expected” ship dates that were announced only by Gurman do we need before MacRumors writers, and the others on the Gurman regurgitation re-blogging beat, start to wonder whether it's really the case, as Gurman's reporting would have us believe , that every single product from Apple winds up shipping months or even years later than intended?

Maybe Gurman's right, and Apple hasn't shipped a single product on schedule since like maybe the original AirPods back in 2016 (an absolute banger of a scoop, from before Gurman left 9to5Mac for Bloomberg).

Or, and I'm just tossing this out there, maybe the way companies that are good at shipping new products actually ship new products is by setting aggressive, probably impossible, internal milestones to keep the entire team inside the company and manufacturing partners in the supply chain moving with urgency until the thing is actually ready to announce and ship. And that by reporting these milestones as actual expected ship dates, repeatedly, it makes Mark Gurman and Bloomberg News wrong, not the products late, when those dates are missed without the products ever having been announced. Something like that could happen when the incentive structure of a news publication is based on whether the reporting moves stock prices , not whether it turns out to be accurate.

I'm sure it's just the case, though, that Apple has been unable to ship anything new on schedule for close to a decade.

entry.title: Google Search, More Machine Now Than Man, Begins Requiring JavaScript
entry.content:
Kyle Wiggers, writing at TechCrunch:

Google says it has begun requiring users to turn on JavaScript, the widely used programming language to make web pages interactive, in order to use Google Search. In an email to TechCrunch, a company spokesperson claimed that the change is intended to “better protect” Google Search against malicious activity, such as bots and spam, and to improve the overall Google Search experience for users. The spokesperson noted that, without JavaScript, many Google Search features won't work properly and that the quality of search results tends to be degraded.

The Google spokesperson told TechCrunch that, on average, “fewer than .1%” of searches on Google are done by people who disable JavaScript. That's no small number at Google scale. Google processes around 8.5 billion searches per day, so one can assume that millions of people performing searches through Google aren't using JavaScript.

One of Google's motivations here may be inhibiting third-party tools that give insights into Google Search trends and traffic. According to a post on Search Engine Roundtable on Friday, a number of “rank-checking” tools — tools that indicate how websites are performing in search engines — began experiencing issues with Google Search around the time Google's JavaScript requirement came into force.

I long ago stopped being a fan (or regular user) of Google Search, but the SEO industry is worse (to keep the Obi-Wan Kenobi quote references going from my headline, you'll never find a more wretched hive of scum and villainy than “SEO experts”), so I'm amenable to an argument from Google that this is a justifiable step in their never-ending war with SEO scammers seeking to game search results in their favor.

But the bottom line is that with this change, Google Search is more of an app than it is a website. A website is a server where you can make requests over the HTTP protocol and get results in HTML format. A server that communicates with clients via executable JavaScript is not a website. Whether it's a justifiable decision or not, I don't buy for a second that it's a necessary decision on Google's part. Thus I find this decision sad, but given the course Google has been on for the last 15 years or so, I'm also unsurprised. Old original Google was a company of and for the open web. Post 2010-or-so Google is a company that sees the web as a de facto proprietary platform that it owns and controls. Those who experience the web through Google Chrome and Google Search are on that proprietary not-closed-per-se-but-not-really-open web.

Requiring JavaScript for Google Search is not about the fact that 99.9 percent of humans surfing the web have JavaScript enabled in their browsers. It's about taking advantage of that fact to tightly control client access to Google Search results. But the nature of the true open web is that the server sticks to the specs for the HTTP protocol and the HTML content format, and clients are free to interpret that as they see fit. Original, novel, clever ways to do things with website output is what made the web so thrilling, fun, useful, and amazing. This JavaScript mandate is Google's attempt at asserting that it will only serve search results to exactly the client software that it sees fit to serve. That's Google's right. But it's sad.

Here's a good thread on Hacker News discussing the change , with some interesting commentary on the state of the no-JavaScript web. Also worth pointing out that Kagi , the best search engine in the world, works fine without JavaScript .

I'll end with my longstanding hot take , which, as the years go on, seems more and more obviously true and no longer a hot take at all: The web would be better off if browsers had never added support for scripting. The web would be much faster; much better for its original purpose of delivering content to consume, not software to interact with; and much more secure and private. More control would remain in the hands of client software — and thus in the hands of users — than server-side.

entry.title: David Lynch Dies at 78
entry.content:
Brian Tallerico, writing for RogerEbert.com:

David Lynch saw my dreams. As a teenager growing up in suburban America in the '80s, “Blue Velvet” and “Twin Peaks” hit like a bolt of lightning. Not only did they capture something about the sinister, surreal underbelly of life under the picket fences, but they said something directly to anyone who thought they could be an artist: You don't have to do what everyone else is doing.

Lynch was one of those creative voices who found his own octave, doing for film what people like David Bowie or Prince did for music, shattering expectations of what a piece of art could be. Even when his work missed the mark, which was rare, Lynch was never anything less than a singular artist, a creator who never once succumbed to the desire to please that derails so much potential in his industry. When people point to Lynch works like “ Mulholland Dr. ” or “ The Straight Story ” or even those of us who love “ Lost Highway ,” it's not just that specific film that speaks to them — it's the sense that the potential of the form is limitless as long as people like Lynch are involved. The entire art form was shifted by him and is now lessened by his absence. We owe it to him to burst through the doors he opened. [...]

Lynch's fifth film, 1990's “Wild at Heart” would be one of his most divisive — it's often pointed to as Lynch at his most excessive — but it was what he did on television that same year that rocked the entertainment world: “Twin Peaks.透明I could write a book about what “Twin Peaks” meant to a 15-year-old entertainment junkie. To summarize, it exploded the potential of the form. People who watch “Twin Peaks” over three decades later need to understand the TV landscape on which it landed. I'm not saying there wasn't quality TV in the '80s, but there was less risk-taking than in the 2020s, and watching the saga of Laura Palmer next to formulaic dramas or laugh-track-heavy sitcoms felt like a true shock to the system. For more on “Twin Peaks” and why it mattered, check this out .

A thought that's been swirling in my head for 30-some years but only today properly crystalized: Lynch is the only artist I love whose work I largely don't “get”. Nothing exemplifies that more than Twin Peaks — I never stopped thinking that there must be something there that I simply wasn't getting, but I absolutely loved it. But now I realize that's a big part of why I loved it. I don't like to be confused but I do like it when it's David Lynch confusing me. It's still hard to believe that show was on commercial network TV.

Like Kubrick, he was quick to embrace new technology as it became available and to see its artistic potential. He sung the praises of digital video and declared himself done with film years ahead of the industry. Lynch called bullshit when he saw it, and he always let you know what he really thought . Also like Kubrick (whom Lynch, unsurprisingly, named first when asked his favorite filmmakers ), Lynch's later years were sparse with new work, but the work he delivered continued to elevate the art form. 2017's 18-episode Twin Peaks: The Return was so utterly Lynchian — a perfect capstone to a remarkable career.

entry.title: Bob Uecker, Mr. Baseball, Dies at 90
entry.content:
Ray Ratto, writing for Defector, gets it right. Bob Uecker was just the best:

He was the face and voice of baseball cinema, the man whose line-reading made “Ju-uuu-st a bit outside” so good that “iconic” doesn't remotely cover its impact. Even if you're not a seamhead, you likely came across Bob Uecker and smiled.

So Thursday's announcement that Uecker has died at age 90, due to small cell lung cancer, came as a blow. Nine decades is a good long run, but there was never a sense that he was running out of material; Uecker was still a joy to hear on Brewers broadcasts even in Year 54 of being the voice of Wisconsin baseball for two-and-a-half generations. The reaction to his passing was unanimous in the same ways and for the same reasons that the response to Vin Scully's death was unanimous — it was an outpouring of both sadness at the loss and gratitude for all the time we got to spend with him. In an epochally angry time in America, at a moment when it isn't hard to find even anti-puppy polemics with a keystroke, Uecker gets a pass from most everyone. Yes he defined baseball, but he also managed to become more than merely Mister Baseball. From the moment of his first appearance on Johnny Carson's definitive version of the Tonight Show, which Uecker earned merely by mastering the tripartite arts of comedy writing, unabashed self-deprecation, and martini-dry humor, he was recognizable as that rarest of Americans, the guy you'd sit back down to listen to even if you were already halfway out the door. Put another way, Norm Macdonald thought he was one of the funniest men he ever met. Beat that with a stick.

MLB.com has a fine obituary that includes a slew of links and videos. Uecker, 90 years old, was on the call for the Brewers right up until the bitter end of last season , when they fell to the Mets in the 9th inning. His final words as a broadcaster : “I'm telling you. That one — had some sting on it.” So does this one.

If you want to lose a few hours in laughter, head down the rabbit hole of Uecker's 100-some appearances on Carson . Here's the first one that just came up for me now, a 1976 appearance where Uecker, utterly deadpan as ever, makes Mel Brooks spit out his coffee.

entry.title: 'Twenty Years of Kraft'
entry.content:
Bryan Bedell, on the Field Notes Dispatches blog:

The anniversary date of “Field Notes” varies a bit, depending on who you ask. Aaron Draplin first used the name (typeset, of course, in all-caps Futura Bold) on a customized one-off red hardcover notebook in 2002. Our “official line” sets the birth of the company in mid-2007, when Coudal Partners and Aaron first printed a batch of 3-Packs for the “Swap Meat,” followed shortly by the establishment of “Field Notes Brand” as an actual thing.

But a good case can be made that the very first Field Notes were made in “early January 2005,” making this, January 2025, an important 20th anniversary. This was the first “big” run (200 books, big for the time!), hand-printed by Aaron on his desktop Gocco silkscreen rig.* This was the first use of a kraft-paper cover. The general look-and-feel, while a bit narrower, is mostly dialed-in. The body is graph paper, even if it's trimmed-down letter-size dungeon-mapping blue-ruled graph paper.

I carry a Field Notes (or at least Field-Notes-sized — I dally with others, but always come home) notebook in my back pocket wherever I go. And because I'm a pack rat, I number, date, and keep them all. I just filled up volume 114 (9 Dec 2024 – 13 Jan 2025) and started volume 115 yesterday.

Funny enough, I started my pocket notebook habit in 2006, a year before Field Notes became a thing. And I was greatly dissatisfied with the various notebooks I'd tried prior to Field Notes. Hardcover Moleskines were too thick and uncomfortable to sit on, and their softcover notebooks started falling apart at the seams after just a few weeks. And then in 2007 my friend Jim Coudal offhandedly mentioned that he was starting a project with Aaron Draplin called Field Notes, and son of a bitch if the notebooks they were making weren't exactly what I craved. The rest is history — a lot of ink, a lot of pages. Mostly nonsense, but some occasional gems and fond memories. The first page of my first notebook has a list of strollers to consider for my then-toddler son; he's now a junior in college. And flipping through volume 4 just now, I came upon this one-page outline from September 2006 for a never-published episode in the Anthropomorphized Brushed Metal Interface Theme saga, wherein Brushed Metal, Aqua, and the just-released iTunes 7 visit a bitter classic Mac OS 9 Platinum theme on his deathbed in the hospital. (Platinum: “You fucked me on iTunes. The two of you.” And: “Steve never loved me, I'm the only one.”)

When in doubt, write it down.

entry.title: 'TikTok Is Just the Beginning'
entry.content:
Noah Smith, writing at Noahpinion:

As many observers have noted, this tells us two important things. First, it tells us that Chinese officials are the ones calling the shots with regards to TikTok. This should be no surprise, given that ByteDance is legally required to obey CCP directives.

Second, the refusal to sell the app tells us that the Chinese government would rather see TikTok destroyed than see it fall into American hands. Notably, that same government put up little fuss back in 2020 when the US forced a Chinese company to sell the gay dating app Grindr to an American company. Why shut down TikTok and leave untold billions of dollars on the table, instead of just selling the thing like Grindr was sold?

One possibility is that it's an attempt to make young Americans angry, in the hopes that they'll demand that Trump and Congress repeal the 2024 law. But a simpler explanation is that Chinese leaders simply think that TikTok, unlike other apps, is so important that they would rather destroy it than see it escape their control.

TikTok is an ingenious propaganda platform. A mass audience — which skews very young — finds it addictively entertaining. But research studies show that the platform squelches topics that aren't aligned with the CCP. Smith cites two; here's the abstractof the second one , which was published just last month:

Three studies explored how TikTok, a China-owned social media platform, may be manipulated to conceal content critical of China while amplifying narratives that align with Chinese Communist Party objectives. Study I employed a user journey methodology, wherein newly created accounts on TikTok, Instagram, and YouTube were used to assess the nature and prevalence of content related to sensitive Chinese Communist Party (CCP) issues, specifically Tibet, Tiananmen Square, Uyghur rights, and新疆。 The results revealed that content critical of China was made far less available than it was on Instagram and YouTube.

Study II, an extension of Study I, investigated whether the prevalence of content that is pro- and anti-CCP on TikTok, Instagram, and YouTube aligned with user engagement metrics (likes and comments), which social media platforms typically use to amplify content 。 The results revealed a disproportionately high ratio of pro-CCP to anti-CCP content on TikTok, despite users engaging significantly more with anti-CCP content, suggesting propagandistic manipulation.

Study III involved a survey administered to 1214 Americans that assessed their time spent on social media platforms and their perceptions of China. Results indicated that TikTok users, particularly heavy users, exhibited significantly more positive attitudes towards China's human rights record and expressed greater favorability towards China as a travel destination.

Back to Smith:

In other words, the Chinese government is actively silencing the views of Americans who try to criticize that government. Somehow I doubt that the First Amendment's protection of free speech was intended to protect the right of foreign governments to silence American individuals from speaking their mind in popular public forums. That would be a very strange definition of “freedom of speech”. Of course, I am no legal scholar, so I'll have to wait on the Supreme Court to make that judgement, and abide by what they decide.

★
